intro: Soehrensia oreopepon, commonly known as the Hawaiian orangeberry, is a member of the Rubiaceae family. It is a small evergreen shrub native to the island of Oahu in Hawaii. The plant is characterized by its glossy, dark green leaves and clusters of small, orange-red berries that mature in the fall. The berries are edible and have a sweet, tangy flavor, making them a traditional food of the Hawaiian people. Due to its ecological and cultural significance, it is also considered a rare and endangered species.
